articles.headline: Parties’ Divergent Realities Challenge Biden’s Defense of Democracy
articles.snippet: The president seeks to confront threats to American institutions, but Americans are deeply divided on who is imperiling them.
articles.abstract: The president seeks to confront threats to American institutions, but Americans are deeply divided on who is imperiling them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The good news is that deeply divided Americans agree on at least one thing. The bad news is they share the view that their nearly two-and-a-half-century-old democracy is in danger — and disagree drastically about who is threatening it.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Blake Hounshell

articles.headline: Lawsuits Over Tragedies Can Drag On. Not in the Florida Condo Collapse.
articles.snippet: A little over a year after the Champlain Towers South fell, the Surfside condo victims’ families are about to be compensated for their losses.
articles.abstract: A little over a year after the Champlain Towers South fell, the Surfside condo victims’ families are about to be compensated for their losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Each day, before the unusual hearings unfolded inside Judge Michael A. Hanzman’s Miami courtroom this summer, the judge’s aides would stock the judge’s bench, the lawyers’ tables and the witness stand with boxes of tissues. At some point, they knew, almost everyone would cry, and each excruciating presentation would end with Judge Hanzman offering people hugs.

articles.headline: Why Aren’t Student Loans Simple? Because This Is America.
articles.snippet: Instead of making higher education free, we subsidize it later through repayment plans and attempts at debt cancellation. The complexity is disrespectful.
articles.abstract: Instead of making higher education free, we subsidize it later through repayment plans and attempts at debt cancellation. The complexity is disrespectful.
articles.lead_paragraph: If we want higher education to cost less, we should make it cheaper when people enroll.

articles.headline: Britain’s Pubs Are Threatened by ‘Alarming’ Rise in Energy Bills
articles.snippet: Businesses have fewer protections than residential users against higher electricity and gas costs, and industry groups warn of widespread closings this winter.
articles.abstract: Businesses have fewer protections than residential users against higher electricity and gas costs, and industry groups warn of widespread closings this winter.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — With every day that passes, Lindsey Armstrong’s dilemma gets worse as Britain’s energy crisis closes in on her pub.

articles.headline: How Fake GPS Coordinates Are Leading to Lawlessness on the High Seas
articles.snippet: A technology enabling the transmission of fake locations to carry out murky or even illegal business operations could have profound implications for the enforcement of international law.
articles.abstract: A technology enabling the transmission of fake locations to carry out murky or even illegal business operations could have profound implications for the enforcement of international law.
articles.lead_paragraph: The scrappy oil tanker waited to load fuel at a dilapidated jetty projecting from a giant Venezuelan refinery on a December morning. A string of abandoned ships listed in the surrounding turquoise Caribbean waters, a testament to the country’s decay after years of economic hardships and U.S. sanctions.

articles.headline: How a Record Cash Haul Vanished for Senate Republicans
articles.snippet: The campaign arm of Senate Republicans had collected $181.5 million by the end of July — but spent 95 percent of it. A big investment in digital, and hyperaggressive tactics, have not paid off.
articles.abstract: The campaign arm of Senate Republicans had collected $181.5 million by the end of July — but spent 95 percent of it. A big investment in digital, and hyperaggressive tactics, have not paid off.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was early 2021, and Senator Rick Scott wanted to go big. The new chairman of the Senate Republican campaign arm had a mind to modernize the place. One of his first decisions was to overhaul how the group raised money online.

articles.headline: India’s Electric Vehicle Push Is Riding on Mopeds and Rickshaws
articles.snippet: The country’s success with two- and three-wheeled vehicles that sell for as little as $1,000 could be a template for other developing countries.
articles.abstract: The country’s success with two- and three-wheeled vehicles that sell for as little as $1,000 could be a template for other developing countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the United States, luxury-car buyers are snapping up Teslas and other electric cars that cost more than $60,000, and even relatively cheap models cost more than $25,000.
articles.byline: By Emily Schmall, Jack Ewing and Atul Loke

articles.headline: Movie Theaters Had a Great Summer. But There’s a Plot Twist.
articles.snippet: Hits like “Top Gun: Maverick” seemed to lead a revival, yet one chain is preparing for bankruptcy, another is awash in debt and blockbusters are in short supply.
articles.abstract: Hits like “Top Gun: Maverick” seemed to lead a revival, yet one chain is preparing for bankruptcy, another is awash in debt and blockbusters are in short supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hits just keep on coming. But not the ones movie theaters need.

articles.headline: Russia’s Unfounded Claims of Secret U.S. Bioweapons Linger On and On
articles.snippet: Without providing evidence, the Kremlin is pressing allegations that the U.S. operates labs in Ukraine and beyond. This week, it has called an investigative session in Geneva.
articles.abstract: Without providing evidence, the Kremlin is pressing allegations that the U.S. operates labs in Ukraine and beyond. This week, it has called an investigative session in Geneva.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States secretly manufactured biological weapons in Ukraine. It trained birds to carry pathogens into Russia. It created Covid-19. It operated laboratories in Nigeria that engineered this year’s outbreak of monkeypox.

articles.headline: Wary of Cold Days and Hot Tempers, Europe’s Leaders Vow Economic Relief
articles.snippet: Germany, Sweden and the Czech Republic announced measures to populations feeling the bite of rising inflation and energy costs tied to war in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Germany, Sweden and the Czech Republic announced measures to populations feeling the bite of rising inflation and energy costs tied to war in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — European governments moved this weekend to soften the blow of soaring costs and a deepening energy crisis triggered by the war in Ukraine, and scrambled to prepare for the possibility of social unrest as the days grow colder.

articles.headline: As Midterms Near, Election Rule Raises Dilemma for Trump Inquiries
articles.snippet: Justice Department officials are debating how an unwritten rule should affect the criminal investigations into Jan. 6 and the former president’s handling of sensitive documents.
articles.abstract: Justice Department officials are debating how an unwritten rule should affect the criminal investigations into Jan. 6 and the former president’s handling of sensitive documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the midterm elections near, top Justice Department officials are weighing whether to temporarily scale back work in criminal investigations involving former President Donald J. Trump because of an unwritten rule forbidding overt actions that could improperly influence the vote, according to people briefed on the discussions.

articles.headline: As Russia Chokes Europe’s Gas, France Enters Era of Energy ‘Sobriety’
articles.snippet: The government is helping residents with soaring gas and electric costs, but some businesses are already shutting down amid fears of rationing and blackouts.
articles.abstract: The government is helping residents with soaring gas and electric costs, but some businesses are already shutting down amid fears of rationing and blackouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: A factory making iconic French bistro glasses is idling its furnaces to offset soaring energy costs. Cities around France are turning off streetlamps and other outdoor lighting to curb electricity use. In Normandy, some schools will start heating classrooms by burning wood to conserve natural gas.

articles.headline: A Hawkish Diplomat Takes Control, Facing Hard Times and Johnson’s Ghost
articles.snippet: Coming to power during the worst economic crisis since the Thatcher era, Liz Truss will need all her ideological dexterity — some call it opportunism — to succeed.
articles.abstract: Coming to power during the worst economic crisis since the Thatcher era, Liz Truss will need all her ideological dexterity — some call it opportunism — to succeed.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON —  As a passionate 19-year-old student at Oxford in 1994, Elizabeth Truss called for a referendum to abolish the British monarchy, telling an audience of fellow Liberal Democrats, “We do not believe that people should be born to rule.”
